text:
Dr* Harry J. Skornia
Page 2
September 1, 1954
I talked to Mr. Toogood in Chicago for a few minutes
on August 11, and he stressed the importance of cleanli¬
ness for proper operation of the machines. If at some
future date the duplicating setup is moved, the duplica¬
tors should be placed in a room separate from the room
where tapes are wrapped, packed and unpacked. I believe
that we should have plastic covers made for the machines,
and they should be covered at night or when the room is
being swept. We should also have buildings and grounds
keep the window wells clean so that dust is not blown
in from this source.
The following is a list of tubes to be replaced.
Those in the duplicators check low but not so low that
immediate replacement is required.
